Once you have posted your request, please check the catalog for requests that you can help others with.
All threads and images should pertain to "work-safe" material. For adult content please use /r/ - Requests and for help with personal matters please use /adv/ - Advice.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1315941
when we are faced with an obstacle, we can either try our best to get past it, or we can accept that it's hopeless and do nothing about it
i think people feel stronger when they choose the former because they gain confidence knowing they can handle the challenge of stress and hardship. after overcoming an extraordinary challenge, problems in their future might feel small and much more manageable
but people that choose the latter have a bad mindset about their future and have given up on resolving their problems. they might pick up bad habits like drinking or drugs to cope or even choose suicide to escape from it entirely
>crimes against another
some people will do whatever it takes to solve their problems, even if it's at the expense of someone else, because we often (but not always) place our own sense of comfort and well-being first and crime can just be the easy way out for them

i hope that was what you were asking?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1315941
>how problems can make or break
>thinks that commiting crimes against another person is ok

You're confused there. You're conflating two very separate ideas. People with both high and low psychological resilience commit crimes against people.

Eg. a lot of theft runs along the reasoning "they have it, I want it,I'm taking it". This is less about resilience and more about gratification. There can be elements of "I don't have enough money" but again that's not lack of resilience, that's greed. People can be greedy and resilient or greedy and not resilient.

There's a self-deception or stupidity sometimes like "that person has that, they must be rich so it won't matter they can replace it" or "that person has it, they've got it easy, I've worked hard but haven't got it, it should be mine" or "that person's race/class has oppressed me so I deserve it". Again, nothing to do with resilience. Faulty reasoning, selfishness, greed, lack of compassion, lack of empathy, resilience is not a factor.

Anyway, the term you are looking for about making or breaking a person is probably best described by "psychological resilience".

Cognitive Behavioural Therapists would have you believe that resilience can be increased by changing one's thoughts/cognitions and behaviours. I don't know if that's true but CBT has pretty good research to back it up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
WebM for Lazys v3.22.0, Mode Variable, Enable Audio, adjust Video CRF from experience derived from duration and dimensions and how busy the source is.
It's depends a lot on the source: fast dits, zooms, pans and rotates are bitrate hogs; nice calm oldschool animations are best. My examples: >>>/wsg/4925354 is 90 seconds at 464p; >>>/aco/6998967 very busy, very NSFW with 14 seconds at 720p; the "scratchy" Josephine Baker one took 3 MB to do just 20 seconds at 400p; >>>/wsg/4929484 is 60+ seconds at 1080p but I had to force quality down to fit (artefacts visible). I sometimes leave my CRF settings in the filename. Also, avoid resizing as it degrades quality, better is shorter durations.
Last, I rarely use ffmpeg command line for difficult cases.

posts.com:
I'll try go with shit I watched when I was young. I would say these would be closer to 7-8 than 4 but here you go. These are all based off their english dub form.

Medabots - personally didn't watch this until I was like 10 or 11 I think but I think dub is appropriate for that age range for the most part. There's one episode where the kids go to the bad part of town, and encounter some drunks that the dub tries to censor with it's spoken dialogue implying their possessed by ghost or something. It's comical as an adult because it's pretty obvious, but as a kid it flew right over my head. There's another episode where characters backstory is being from a country in a civil war. Nothing graphic is shown, or referred to but the implications are obvious an adult, but again flew over my head. These are only 2 episodes I can really find issue with though.

Digimon Adventure - watched when I was 5, and the dub definitely got away with some stuff I'm surprised flew back then. Lots of flashes to white when a human character gets punched or hit. There's also an episode where the main character gets slapped in the face by his mom in flashback. The dub kinda tiptoes around it by not showing the slap at all and cutting forward slightly after it happened, but the character is holding his face with a red mark while his mother berates him. Still blows my mind they got away with this. Otherwise can't think of anything else that bad in the dub.
Ronin Warriors is one I watched when I was 5-6 as well. Think power rangers but Samurai. Not sure if the holds up or really adhers to modern standard though

+ 4chan(nel) strips .exif

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

>>1313872
lower video bit rate = more compression = smaller file = lower picture quality
higher video bit rate = less compression = larger file = higher picture quality

A high video bit rate must be why the video file is so large.
Different video bit rates will result in different file sizes.
And fyi, audio bit rate has little to do with file size. It's all about the video bit rate and screen size.

Does anyone have a list or something explaining all the 'flags' or arguments in little letters I have to use? For example:
-S
-s
-R
and so on and so forth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1315493
`man pacman`
Then, type -i (dash, i, enter) to toggle case sensitive search.
Press slash (/) and type the flag you're looking for.
Press slash again to go down the search results.

In short, in pacman, uppercase switches are operations and lowercase switches are options for these operations.

>-S
Sync operation.
Used for installing packages (e.g. `pacman -S vim` or upgrading the system (e.g. `pacman -Syu`).

>-s
Option for the query (`-Q`) or remove (`-R`) operation.
With query, that's to search within the locally-installed packages.
With remove, that's to recursively remove no longer needed dependencies.

>-R
Remove operation, for removing one or more packages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1315493
https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Pacman/Rosetta
If you are a casual user, you probably only need to install or remove packages.

>-Syu
I always use this to install anything, because it also automatically updates everything.
If you aren't an updooter, then -S is enough.

>-Rs
Remove a package + remove everything that depends on it (unless something else depends on it).
This cleans your system and prevents orphaned packages.

>-Scc
Deletes all caches. You don't really need to keep it all, don't you?

Use pamac.

It's also worth familiarizing yourself with pacman, the package manager of Arch Linux (which Manjaro is based on).
https://wiki.manjaro.org/index.php/Pacman_Overview

Since Manjaro is based on Arch, a lot of what applies to Arch also applies to Manjaro.
So feel free to peruse the Arch Wiki.

>I have trouble using the makepkg command
That's for building packages.
pamac/pacman give you packages that are built already.
Typically, makepkg only used when building AUR packages manually.
pamac takes care of that for you.
There's also yay and other AUR helpers:
https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/AUR_helpers

So, I'm working on translating a chatbot trained on English to Spanish. I have tested it with several translations modules but none of them met my needs. The problem is mainly related of how genders are handled with the first person, the gender of the first person is undefined in English while in spanish there are specific marks to point if the speaker is male or female; for instance "I'm a teacher" could mean "Onions profesor" y "Onions profesora" in Spanish. This causes problem because usually the bot is a girl and it gets turned into masculine during the translation. What I want is a way to tell the translator that everytime it encounters the first person it assumes a given gender, for instance:
>Translate("I'm a teacher","female") = "Onions profesora"
>Translate("I'm a teacher","male") = "Onions profesor"
Is there a way to work around this problem. I hope it's clear enough, thanks in advance.

>>1314922
Smash Hit - A game where you have no player character and the camera just flies through a 3D world. You have to shoot metal balls to break glass obstacles that will hit you otherwise.

PinOut - A fairly generic pinball game but with some interesting powerups.

Trainyard Express - This is a puzzle game where you have to route colored trains to corresponding slots. You have a finite amount of space on the board, and there are really difficult challenges, sometimes with combining colors to make new ones, sometimes with using the finite amount of space to make trains "combine" so they all arrive at the exact same time. The graphics are basic, but the aesthetic is suuuuuper modern and minimalistic. Easily one of my favorite Android games ever. It's no longer on the Google play store, but you can download an old APK here if you want to try it: https://trainyard-express.en.uptodown.com/android/download

Auralux - Basically babby's first RTS. Super minimalistic game, where your "money" is also your "army". You start with a single planet, and it produces a certain number of units. When enemy units collide, they disappear. When units flow into an enemy planet, the "HP" of the planet drains until the planet becomes neutral. When when a player send enough units to flow into a neutral planet, they take over the planet and it starts producing units too. The AI in the game can be a bit stupid, but the game is always fun or challenging. There's also an Auralux 2, which is better than the first one in almost every conceivable way, but both are worth playing at least once.

Traffic Rush - A super simple game where traffic is flowing into a 4-way intersection and you can either swipe at the cars to make them speed up, or tap on them to make them stop for a moment. It can get hectic the longer the game goes on as traffic flow increases. The ads are fucking awful, so definitely only play in offline mode unless you want to fork over some money to remove the ads.

>>1314547
It's the responsibility of the person who seeking help to make it as easy as possible to have that help provided. You made numbers up out of nothing. You didn't show working. How I am supposed to know where you went wrong? If you haven't had it drilled into you to show working that's your problem.

But now that you have shown some working.

9.42" is the circumference at C
1 revolution gives a displacement of 9.42"
60 revolutions is 60 * 9.42" = 565"
120 revolutions is 1130"
Now you see why writing 1179 was both wrong and unhelpful. It's close to an answer, not a right answer, but no one can know how you got to being close to a wrong answer.

You might have left them off while typing on computer but in written work you should be in the habit of writing proper mathematical statements including units, especially when you're using funny burgerland units that mean you just don't off by powers of 10. That way you can check cancellation of units properly.

9.42 (inch / rev) * 60 (rev / min) = 565 (inch / min)

565 (inch / min) * 1/12 (feet / inch) = 47.1 (feet / min)

You are correct with the shaft speed of 30 rpm at A. You are correct that the shaft at B rotates at double the rpm of A.

In the absence of any contrary information, we've assumed a rigid system. For a rigid body in pure translation the linear velocity is the same at all points of that body. A corresponding rule applies to a rigid body in rotation for its rotational velocity. Except at the axis where you run into problems about mathematical points which have 0 radius, all points of a rigid rotating body have the same rotational velocity ω.

If C had a 3" radius, it would have the same ω as if it had a 3" diameter because all parts must perform the same number of revolutions per unit time, but with a larger radius any point on its circumference would have a greater instantaneous linear velocity v.
